entry.et: Middle English, from Old English; akin to Old High German fingar finger

def.dt: :any of the five terminating members of the hand :a digit of the forelimb
:one other than the thumb
:something that resembles a finger a narrow finger of land
:a part of a glove into which a finger is inserted
:a projecting piece (as a pawl for a ratchet) brought into contact with an object to affect its motion
:the breadth of a finger
:interest share often used in the phrase have a finger in the pie
:bird 10 usually used with the
:to touch or feel with the fingers
:to play (a musical instrument) with the fingers
:to play (as notes or chords) with a specific fingering
:to mark the notes of (a music score) as a guide in playing
:to point out :identify
:to extend into or penetrate in the shape of a finger
:to touch or handle something
:to use the fingers in playing a musical instrument
:to have a certain fingering used of a musical instrument
:to extend in the shape or manner of a finger
:a small water bowl for rinsing the fingers at the table
:a food that is to be held with the fingers for eating
:any of several holes in the side of a wind instrument (as a recorder) which may be covered or left open by the fingers to change the pitch of the tone
:a hole (as in a telephone dialect or a bowling ball) into which the finger is placed to provide a grip
:a technique of spreading pigment on paper chiefly with the fingers
:a picture so produced
:the act of making explicit and often unfair accusations of blame
:communication by signs made with the fingers called also dactylology
:a method of setting hair by dampening with water or wave solution and forming waves or curls with the fingers and a comb
group of long narrow lakes W cen New York comprising Cayuga, Seneca, Keuka, Canandaigua, Skaneateles, Owasco, & several smaller lakes
